dn12:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at Sālavatikā.
dn12:1.3: Now at that time the brahmin Lohicca was living in Sālavatikā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
dn12:2.1: Now at that time Lohicca had the following harmful misconception:
dn12:2.2: “Should an ascetic or brahmin achieve some skillful quality, they ought not inform anyone else. For what can one person do for another?
dn12:2.3: Suppose someone cut off an old bond, only to create another new bond.
dn12:2.4: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one person do for another?”
dn12:3.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Sālavatikā, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
dn12:3.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
dn12:3.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
dn12:3.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
dn12:3.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

dn12:16.0: 2. Three Teachers Who Deserve to Be Reprimanded
dn12:16.1: Lohicca, there are three kinds of teachers in the world who deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:16.2: When someone reprimands such teachers, the reprimand is true, correct, legitimate, and blameless.
dn12:16.4: Firstly, take a teacher who has not reached the goal of the ascetic life for which they went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn12:16.6: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’

dn12:16.8: That teacher deserves to be reprimanded:
dn12:16.9: ‘Venerable, you haven’t reached the goal of the ascetic life; and when you teach disciples
dn12:16.11: they proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
dn12:16.12: It’s like a man who makes advances on a woman though she pulls away, or embraces her though she turns her back.
dn12:16.13: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one do for another?’
dn12:16.15: This is the first kind of teacher who deserves to be reprimanded.

dn12:19.0: 3. A Teacher Who Does Not Deserve to Be Reprimanded
dn12:19.1: When he had spoken, Lohicca said to the Buddha,
dn12:19.2: “But worthy Gotama, is there a teacher in the world who does not deserve to be reprimanded?”
dn12:20.1: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
dn12:20.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
dn12:20.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
dn12:21.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
dn12:21.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
dn12:21.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
dn12:21.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
dn12:21.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn12:21.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn12:22.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
dn12:23.1: And how, Lohicca, is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?
dn12:23.2: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
dn12:23.4: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
dn12:23.6: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
dn12:24.1: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
dn12:24.3: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
dn12:24.5: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
dn12:24.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
dn12:25.1: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
dn12:25.2: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
dn12:25.3: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
dn12:25.4: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn12:25.5: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
dn12:25.6: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
dn12:25.15: They refrain from running errands and messages;
dn12:25.19: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
dn12:25.21: The shorter section on ethics is finished.
dn12:26.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
dn12:26.2: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. They refrain from such injury to plants and seeds.
dn12:27.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
dn12:27.2: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.
dn12:27.3: They refrain from storing up such goods.
dn12:28.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
dn12:28.2: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; pole-acrobatics and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
dn12:29.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
dn12:29.2: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
dn12:30.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
dn12:30.2: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
dn12:31.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn12:31.2: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
dn12:31.3: They refrain from such beautification and adornment.
dn12:32.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk.
dn12:32.2: This includes such topics as talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
dn12:32.3: They refrain from such low talk.
dn12:33.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
dn12:33.2: They say such things as: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!’
dn12:33.3: They refrain from such argumentative talk.
dn12:34.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
dn12:34.2: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: ‘Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.’
dn12:35.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things. They refrain from such deceit and flattery.
dn12:35.3: The middle section on ethics is finished.
dn12:36.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn12:36.2: This includes such fields as limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying lifespan, chanting for protection, and divining omens from wild animals.
dn12:36.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn12:37.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn12:37.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.

dn12:38.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.

dn12:39.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.

dn12:40.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.

dn12:41.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn12:42.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn12:42.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn12:43.1: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
dn12:43.2: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
dn12:43.3: In the same way, a mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
dn12:43.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
dn12:43.5: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.
dn12:43.6: The longer section on ethics is finished.
dn12:44.1: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?
dn12:44.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
dn12:44.3: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
dn12:44.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
dn12:44.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
dn12:44.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
dn12:44.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
dn12:44.8: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
dn12:44.9: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
dn12:44.10: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
dn12:44.11: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.
dn12:45.1: And how does a mendicant have mindfulness and situational awareness?
dn12:45.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
dn12:45.3: That’s how a mendicant has mindfulness and situational awareness.
dn12:46.1: And how is a mendicant content?
dn12:46.2: It’s when a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
dn12:46.3: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
dn12:46.4: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
dn12:46.5: That’s how a mendicant is content.
dn12:47.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble sense restraint, this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, and this noble contentment,
dn12:47.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
dn12:47.3: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
dn12:48.1: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
dn12:48.2: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
dn12:48.3: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
dn12:48.4: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
dn12:48.5: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

dn12:54.1: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them thus as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
dn12:54.2: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.
dn12:54.4: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
dn12:55.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn12:55.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
dn12:56.1: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
dn12:56.2: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
dn12:56.3: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:56.4: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:57.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without applying the mind and keeping it connected.
dn12:57.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
dn12:58.1: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time.
dn12:58.2: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
dn12:58.3: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
dn12:58.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:58.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:59.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
dn12:59.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
dn12:60.1: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
dn12:60.2: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
dn12:60.3: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:60.4: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:61.1: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
dn12:61.2: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
dn12:62.1: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
dn12:62.2: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
dn12:62.3: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:62.4: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:63.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision.
dn12:63.3: ‘This body of mine is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
dn12:63.4: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
dn12:64.1: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
dn12:64.2: And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.
dn12:64.3: And someone with clear eyes were to take it in their hand and check it:
dn12:64.4: ‘This beryl gem is naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
dn12:64.5: And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’
dn12:64.6: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision.
dn12:64.10: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:64.11: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:65.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward the creation of a mind-made body.
dn12:65.2: From this body they create another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
dn12:66.1: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
dn12:66.3: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
dn12:66.4: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
dn12:66.6: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
dn12:66.7: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.
dn12:66.9: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
dn12:66.10: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward the creation of a mind-made body.
dn12:66.11: From this body they create another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
dn12:66.12: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:66.13: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:67.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward psychic power.
dn12:67.2: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.
dn12:68.1: Suppose a deft potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
dn12:68.2: Or suppose a deft ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
dn12:68.3: Or suppose a deft goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
dn12:68.4: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward psychic power.
dn12:68.6: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:68.7: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:69.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward clairaudience.
dn12:69.2: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
dn12:70.1: Suppose there was a person traveling along the road. They’d hear the sound of drums, clay drums, horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms. They’d think: ‘That’s the sound of drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of clay drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.’
dn12:70.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward clairaudience.
dn12:70.3: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
dn12:70.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:70.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:71.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward comprehending the minds of others.
dn12:71.2: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.
dn12:71.3: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
dn12:71.4: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.
dn12:71.18: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
dn12:72.1: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot,’ and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots.’
dn12:72.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward comprehending the minds of others.
dn12:72.3: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.
dn12:72.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:72.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:73.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward recollection of past lives.
dn12:73.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn12:74.1: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
dn12:74.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward recollection of past lives.
dn12:74.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:74.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:75.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
dn12:75.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
dn12:76.1: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse at the central square. A person with clear eyes standing there might see humans entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square. They’d think: ‘These are people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square.’
dn12:76.2: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
dn12:76.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
dn12:76.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
dn12:77.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
dn12:77.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
dn12:77.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
dn12:77.4: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
dn12:77.5: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
dn12:77.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
dn12:77.7: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. They’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
dn12:77.8: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they project it and extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
dn12:77.9: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded. When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.”
dn12:78.1: When he had spoken, Lohicca said to the Buddha:
dn12:78.2: “Suppose, worthy Gotama, a person was falling over a cliff, and another person were to grab them by the hair, pull them up, and place them on firm ground.
dn12:78.3: In the same way, when I was falling off a cliff the worthy Gotama pulled me up and placed me on safe ground.
dn12:78.5: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
dn12:78.6: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
dn12:78.7: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
